takeAction.blurb: **Learn** how COVID-19 intensifies inequality around the world.
**Support** the United Nations Development Programme's global work.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Achim Steiner is a global leader in sustainable development and international cooperation.
nodes.whyListen:
Achim Steiner has lived and worked in many countries in Africa, Asia, Europe and the Americas and champions economic development, sustainability and equity. He was elected by the United Nations General Assembly in 2017 to head the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), which works with 170 countries to support poverty eradication and reduction of inequalities and exclusion. He has been a vocal advocate for the Sustainable Development Goals. Prior to UNDP, he was director of the Oxford Martin School and led the UN Environment Programme, where he evolved the concept of a green economy.

The son of German farmers, Steiner was born in Brazil. He graduated with an MA in philosophy, politics and economics from Worcester College, Oxford University and holds an MA from the University of London/School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS).

nodes.whoTheyAre: Sally Kohn searches for common ground among political foes by focusing on the compassion and humanity in everyone.
nodes.whyListen:
Sally Kohn has a powerful vision for a more united United States. She's an activist, writer and author of The Opposite of Hate: A Field Guide To Repairing Our Humanity. She is also on the USA Today Board of Contributors and has been a regular contributor on CNN, Fox News and MSNBC.
A progressive lesbian, Kohn has sparred with some of the most conservative minds on television and sifted through tons of hate mail each day. But she deeply believes in finding our common humanity amidst our political and cultural differences -- the only way any of us can hope to learn, grow and change.

Interested in booking Sally Kohn to speak at your event? Check out the TED Speakers Bureau to learn more.

videoData.description: Developing countries need strong alliances between the public and private sectors to rebuild after COVID-19, says Achim Steiner, administrator for the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). From building virus tracking systems to supporting clean energy projects and expanding health care, hear how the UNDP is creating partnerships between states and the financial, communications, technology and insurance sectors to rebuild stronger, greener economies post-pandemic. (This virtual conversation, hosted by political commentator Sally Kohn and TED global curator Bruno Giussani, was recorded June 8, 2020.)

footnotes.annotation:
"Many people don't realize that on a continent such as Africa, 70, 80 percent of people who earn a living do this on the informal sector."

Estimates for how much the informal economy contributes to employment in the African continent can be found [here](https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/08/3-ways-to-get-africas-informal-economy-on-the-books/), [here](https://www.brookings.edu/blog/africa-in-focus/2018/06/01/figures-of-the-week-informal-employment-in-african-cities/) and [here](https://ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/newsroom/news/WCMS_627189/lang--en/index.htm).

"So when there's a country like Togo that literally in a matter of weeks, set up a cash transfer scheme for close to 3 million people."

As of June 2020, over 1.3 million people have registered for the cash transfer program in Togo. For more, see [here](https://novissi.gouv.tg/en/home-new-en/).

"But we're also providing a tracking system support in order to allow countries to identify how is the virus spreading."

UNDP supports tracking systems in regions such as the [African continent](https://knowledge.uneca.org/covid19/), [Uruguay](https://www.uy.undp.org/content/uruguay/es/home/presscenter/articles/2019/Uruguay_plataforma_MIRA/presentacion_MIRA.html) and [Cape Verde](https://covid19.cv/).

"In the year 2020, you should not be living in a world where 700 to 800 million people actually still go hungry."

According to the [Food Aid Foundation](https://www.foodaidfoundation.org/world-hunger-statistics.html), 821 million people do not have enough food.

"The UNDP has therefore made one of the four main areas in which to work with governments and with the public and the private sector right now, accelerating the transition towards a greener economy is one way to recover out of this crisis."

For more on this, see [this statement](https://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/news-centre/speeches/2020/annual-session-of-the-undp-executive-board.html) to the UNDP Executive Board.

"Because in least developed, the poorest countries, only 20 percent of people have access to internet. In rich countries, 80 percent."

Clarification: According to one [UNDP report](http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/covid-19_and_human_development_0.pdf), the out-of-school rate for primary school-aged children in low human development countries is 86 percent. The same statistic in higher human development countries is 20 percent.

"On the African continent, 600 million people don't even have access to electricity nor to clean water."

Sourcing for this section can be found [here](https://www.seforall.org/news/five-takeaways-from-the-africa-energy-outlook-2019) and [here](https://washdata.org/sites/default/files/documents/reports/2018-01/JMP-2017-Regional-snapshot-Africa.pdf).

"Only 200 or 300 years ago, nine out of 10 people alive on this planet lived in extreme poverty."

The sourcing from this section can be found [here](https://ourworldindata.org/extreme-history-methods).
